Training: Ashley will provide training for each employee associated with the TDI system. This training will include an overview of the process and operating procedures as outlined in 40 CFR 68.71. Refresher training is provided every three (3) years or more often as necessary. General awareness training is provided for all employees.  Ashley documents and maintains records of employee training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.

Mechanical Integrity: Ashley has written documents and programs to maintain the on-going integrity of the equipment used in the TDI process (i.e., storage tanks, piping systems, etc); additionally, inspections, testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance are addressed. Each person who has responsibilities to perform maintenance on the TDI process components receives training at least every three (3) years and more often if necessary. 

Management of Change: Ashley has established and will implement written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures and changes that affect the TDI process. These procedures assure that appropriate considerations are addressed prior to any change. Employees involved in operating a process and maintenance and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected by a change in the process are informed of, and trained in, the change prior to startup of the process or affected part of the process. If a change results in a change in the process safety information, such information is updated accordingly . Executive Summary

(a) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Ashley Furniture Industries, Inc. (Ashley) is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards. An appropriate response to releases of Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) is in the written Risk Management Program. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs will be fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response efforts. 

(b) Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled

The Ashley facility produces polyurethane foam for mattresses and sleep products and is located at 108 Lipford Avenue in Verona, MS.  Polyurethane foam is a product made by combining chemicals (i.e., isocyanates, polyols, and additives) that undergo a chemical reaction as they are injected into a mold cavity. One such chemical is Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) with a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds which is used as an ingredient in the polyurethane foam manufacturing process. The facility will exceed the threshold quantity when operations begin in approximately late August 2021. After reviewing the facility operations and the RMP regulations, it was determined that the entire facility is considered one process. Based on the facility processes and applicable regulations, it was determined that the facility is subject to Program 2 of the RMP regulations.

(c) General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Process Safety Information:  Ashley completed a compilation of written process safety information to be used in conducting the process hazard analysis (PHA). The last PHA was conducted on June 12 and 13, 2021, using the process safety information gathered in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the TDI process. (f) Planned Changes to Improve Safety

In an attempt to ensure a continual improvement in the facility worker protection and release prevention programs, training will be conducted annually on this program. This program requires the attendance of all personnel whose job is related to the TDI system. Additionally, audits will be performed as specified in the RMP plan, which requires Ashley to assess areas of the RMP plan that may need to be changed or improved.

Process Hazard Analysis: Ashley will update and re-validate the PHA as necessary and at least every five (5) years. The PHA was conducted using the methodology specified in 40 CFR 68.67, and was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, including at least one employee who has expertise in the TDI process, and at least one member knowledgeable in the specific PHA methodology used. A system has been established to promptly address the team's findings and recommendations; assure that the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner and that the resolution is documented; document what actions are to be completed; complete actions as soon as possible; develop a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed; and communicate the actions to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

Operating Procedures: Ashley has developed and implemented written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at each operation where TDI is utilized. These written operating procedures are consistent with the process safety information and address steps for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions. These operating procedures are readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the TDI process. These operating procedures are reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice, including changes that result from changes in process chemicals, technology, and equipment, and changes to the facility. Pre-Startup Safety Review: Ashley performs a pre-startup safety review according to 40 CFR 68.77 when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.

Compliance Audits: Ashley will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of 40
CFR, Part 68 at least every three years to verify that procedures developed under 40 CFR, Part 68
are adequate and are being followed. The compliance audit will be conducted by at least one person  knowledgeable in the TDI system. A report of the findings of the audit will be developed. Ashley will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected. Records of the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports will be maintained.

Incident Investigation: Ashley will investigate each incident, which results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of TDI. Incident investigations will be initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The incident investigation team will consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. A report will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation, and Ashley will promptly address and resolve the incident findings and recommendations. Reports are reviewed with all affected personnel whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings including contract employees where applicable . Incident investigations reports are retained for five years.

Employee Participation: Ashley has developed a written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation . The facility consults with employees on the conduct

and development of process hazards analyses and on the development of the other elements of process management. Ashley provides employees access to process hazard analyses and to all other information required to be developed under 40 CFR, Part 68. General awareness training is provided for all employees.

Hot Work Permit: Ashley will issue a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the TDI process.

Contractors: Ashley, when selecting a contractor, obtains and evaluates information regarding the contract owner or operator's safety performance and programs. Ashley informs the contract owner or operator of the known potential toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work and the TDI process. Ashley has developed and implemented safe work practices consistent with 40 CFR 68.69 (d), to control the entrance, presence, and exit of the contract owner or operator and contract employees in the TDI process areas.

(d) Five-year Accident History

The facility is new and therefore has not had any accidental releases from the TDI process that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

(e) Emergency Response Program

Ashley has developed and implemented an emergency response program for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. This program will include the following elements:
1. An emergency management plan, which is maintained on site and contains at least the following elements:
a. Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies;
b. Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary
accidental exposures; and
c. Procedures for emergency response after an accidental release of TDI.
2. Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and  maintenance.
